It seems that the material is dated and there is no desire to upgrade/fix the tutorials.   This is sad.  It opens the door for the competition to displace Udacity eventually but Udacity would probably maintain a fair edge if it continuously improved.

I found the instructions for the project to be verbose and meandering.  You were mixing instruction in with the specifications; I found that very confusing and made it hard for me to follow.  Next the project was comprised of modules I was to complete and modules that were provided as part of the lesson.  During the process of completing my modules, I ran into several bugs in the provided modules.  I found this very irritating, but a friend pointed out that perhaps the bugs in the provided modules were part of the process.  I would suggest that if that was indeed the intention, that you indicate that for others so they can be prepared.  Next, write a concise and clear specification and have the teaching occur someplace else.  However by this time in the course, we should be able to complete this assignment without the additional teaching, reminders and hints.

I enjoy this program!  It is very well structured, everything is coherent and I feel I am building something big. The course takes a huge amount of the free time. I am wondering how others do.

Its great. I was very happy with Project 1 - postgres with Python ETL project was great, I learn some new things. I was also very happy with some of the extra inputs from the assessor with regards to using sqlalchemy to generate the physical data model. However, I was disappointed that the course so far has not covered the practice of using slowly changing dimensions...I hope that this will be covered later. It was also unclear why the projects table template did not use prefixes of DIMN_% and FACT_% to help differentiate the types of tables and therefore the data modeling methodology that they belonged... is this no longer a good practice?   I am now delving in the NoSQL Cassandra data modelling space which is new territory for me. I am very much looking forward to what learning I have ahead of me here.

I am so far excited about the program. This is more so because I am currently going through a down period of my life unfortunately. I have recently had very ugly experiences that looked like failures. There has been a chain of responses from people who have reasons to say that I didn't perform well in the activities and attempts I got involved in, including academic activities and job interviews. On one hand I am honestly  thoroughly downcast. So when I started this Udacity program, one mind kept telling me that I would also receive same responses from my reviewers. But after the assessment of my first project, surprisingly for the first time in many months, the reviewer gave me a positive feedback. So the big question in my mind is, where has my problem come from, all this while? I can't even provide the answer because the Udacity reviewer did an honest review of my work without a special favor to me. Could it be sheer hard luck working aganst me all this while?  Well, I am still continuing with the rest of the program modules and I pray I continue to do well or even better. It has been an interesting and challanging program and it is worth doing, all the same. I have really learnt and been challanged a lot. I would always recommend Udacity programs to people. reviews.content: The program matches my expectations!

I would like more focus on the React lifecycle and hooks (and how they interact). However, it was very good at helping me understand and wrangle with the basics of state and props and components.
So far it has matched my need and expectations and I find the program exciting.

Great learning

This is the best nanodegree I have taken with Udacity (the third in total)!   The tutors are amazing - truly cannot praise them enough. The walkthrough for the Redux section I found particularly useful, as it helped me to figure out what a real-life workflow might look like as I coded along.   The mentors have been super-quick in responding to questions in 'Knowledge', and the review for my first project was also informative and came back within a couple of hours of submission.  Truly top notch and worth every penny. Thank you, and I hope there are more programs like this (if so, let me know which ones! :-) )  Thanks again!
I am happy to attend this training. It is very useful for learning new things and seeing my mistakes.
would be better if the new react hooks were part of the tutorials
Excellent Experience
I am enjoying the program very much

So far the instructors have done a splendid job in explaining all the important concepts of React that too in a very detailed manner. I'm sure anyone can learn React no matter from what background they come from, that is how easy this course content is. Kudos to every effort taken by all the folks in curating this course!!
Great,, It was more than I expected and I appreciate the detailed feedback on my project

I think the critical differentiator with Udacity is the availability of mentors on-demand; you don't need to fit live meetings with them into your schedule or pay for that level of attention, but they are there to get you unstuck when you don't understand something and push you towards doing things a little better. This is perfect especially for someone who has a technical background looking to learn new skills.

title: Product Manager
description:
In this Nanodegree, you will learn foundational skills all product managers use in leading the development of software
products, whether mobile apps, desktop apps, or web platforms for consumers or enterprises.
skills_learnt: Product design sprints , Product prototyping , Product launch , Product scaling

title: C++
description: Learn C++, a high-performance programming language used in the world's most exciting engineering jobs -- from self-driving cars and robotics to web browsers, media platforms, servers, and video games.
skills_learnt: Threading , Concurrent computing , Computer memory architecture , Dynamic memory allocation

reviews.content: The project is very fun and challenging. I like it!

I have already learned and still continuing to learn a lot more in this program. In addition of being able to learn C++ in deep, I also learned how to put them together to create something meaningful throughout projects. The A* algorithm is something that I always had trouble with and this program taught me how to create a A* algorithm from scratch but more important using real world example to find a shortest path between two coordinates was a big 'WoW' for me. In term of expectation, I am speechless because I didn't finish yet the program but I am already happy with the content, and I just want to say thank you Udacity for putting all these together!!

Another positive is the feedback to work was incredibly fast. Really very fast.

I'm very impressed with this program - the combination of 1) short videos; 2) custom reading material (in manageable length snippets); 3) links to applicable web sites with additional detail and; 4) interactive exercises with live explanations - make the program interesting enough to dive in deeply but easy to put aside when other priorities arise. I find the videos with Bjarne Stroustrup to be particularly interesting, providing a fantastic perspective.  The highly responsive mentor help with searchable history and comprehensive project reviews have been the icing on the cake. Thanks.

title: User Experience
description: The UX Fundamentals & Design Research program teaches the core principles of human-centered design, including scoping a design problem, conducting in-depth interviews, creating quantitative surveys, using research data to uncover opportunities, and applying psychology to design sketches with the end user in mind. Participants will learn how to develop a discussion guide, recruit research participants, and synthesize findings in the form of a research report. They will also learn how to translate research findings into low-fidelity prototypes that can be tested with users, design high-fidelity prototypes, and conduct usability tests. Finally, the program teaches advanced user interface principles to build interactive designs that engage users and improve key performance indicators.
skills_learnt: Remote user testing , High fidelity prototypes , Design optimization , Visual style guides

The feedback on the projects has been a highlight (lots of useful tricks discussed), and the lessons are informative. I am enjoying the topics, learning a lot, and looking forward to using the example code provided for my own projects.  My only reservations are with the code-along walkthroughs, for three reasons:  The copy hasn't been reviewed well enough, and I've found misspellings in comments and small bugs in print statements. Easy to fix, but doesn't look great.  Secondly, I'd appreciate slightly more freedom in how to go about solving various problems, rather than the 'write this line of code, then this one' approach. In other courses I've done (General Assembly's Data Science Immersive, Harvard's CS50) the emphasis is more on introducing a package or coding paradigm thoroughly, before letting you solve the problem how you want to.  I fully support giving people some boilerplate code after they've finished a task that details the best approach, but this would be more effective after they've tried struggling along with their own methods and can therefore understand why the model answer is better.  Following on from this, I think more attention could be paid to introducing & explaining the packages used. I've had a lot of experience with scikit-learn and statsmodels, but pomegranate is completely new to me. My learning was hindered by the lack of explanation of the attributes and methods provided with the various class objects (e.g. what bake() does), and given the pomegranate docs aren't as thorough as sklearn, I would have appreciated more help from Udacity.  That said, I still feel like I'm getting my money's worth and am ready to continue!

title: Cloud Developer
description: Elevate your tech skills with our innovative program focused on Cloud Computing, Microservices, and Serverless Technologies. Master the fundamentals of AWS, learn to build and deploy scalable, full-stack applications on the cloud, and grasp the principles of modern cloud architecture. Delve into microservices, understanding architecture patterns, service replication, and independent scaling. Harness the power of serverless technologies, creating REST APIs and implementing security best practices. Our hands-on exercises offer practical experience, equipping you to design, build, and deploy complex applications. Stay ahead in the digital era with our comprehensive tech program.
skills_learnt: Kubernetes , Microservices architecture design , Microservices debugging , CI/CD
prerequisites: HTML , Command line interface basics , Basic web development

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning
description: The Deep Reinforcement Learning Nanodegree has four courses: Introduction to Deep Reinforcement Learning, Value-Based Methods, Policy-Based Methods, and Multi-Agent RL. Students learn to implement classical solution methods, define Markov decision processes, policies, and value functions, and derive Bellman equations. They learn dynamic programming, Monte Carlo methods, temporal-difference methods, deep RL, and apply these techniques to solve real-world problems. They learn to train agents to navigate virtual worlds, generate optimal financial trading strategies, and apply RL to multiple interacting agents.
skills_learnt: Value-based reinforcement learning , Stochastic policy gradients , Reinforce algorithm , Exploration-exploitation dilemma
prerequisites: Intermediate Python , Deep learning framework proficiency , Neural network basics

title: AI Product Manager
description: The AI Product Manager Nanodegree Program offers a comprehensive overview of AI and machine learning for business. It covers the basics of AI, creating a business case for AI, and measuring success. Learners will also learn to create a high-quality dataset, design annotation instructions, and build a medical imaging classification system. The program covers building and training AI models, evaluating results, and measuring impact. The capstone project involves developing a business proposal for an AI product, defining success metrics, scoping the dataset, planning model development, and building a monitoring plan.
skills_learnt: Dataset annotation , Product prototyping , Model evaluation , Product goals

However, I had troubles with understanding some instructions and rejected submissions: 1. The teacher speaks too fast on the pre-project videos. 2. The description under the videos is confusing: should I do what the video suggests? 3. The project instruction about the Proposal.pdf was not clear. I didn't get from the 1st time that I must fill the template instead of writing my own document. 4. The 2 attempts of the project mostly were rejected due to the technical issue with saving the Preview page and I actually could not get it to work properly. I must provide the video with an explanation of the issue and why I cannot satisfy all the reviewers. Suggestion: to standardies the reviewers and the submitters' environment; make the technical instruction very clear (step by step), including what software to use.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning with Pytorch
description: The Intro to Machine Learning with Pytorch program covers machine learning concepts and techniques, with a focus on supervised and unsupervised learning. The program includes three courses and covers topics such as linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, Naive Bayes, support vector machines, neural networks, and clustering. The courses include projects that allow learners to apply these techniques to real-world problems, such as identifying potential donors for a charity and clustering customers based on their spending habits. The program uses Python and PyTorch for implementation and includes lessons on model evaluation and tuning.
skills_learnt: Naive bayes classifiers , Gaussian mixture models , Model evaluation , Support vector machines
prerequisites: Multivariable calculus , Python for data science , Basic supervised machine learning

As with my previous Udacity program, the technical pace is on par with an advanced program at university. For those with missing or rusty prerequisites, I would recommend cursory review of the support material before starting.  If not, you run the risk of requiring extra time to understand core ML fundamentals. If it does not exist, I recommend Udacity provide small example datasets to study for algorithm reinforcement.   The instructors are clearly knowledgeable and convey the concepts efficiently. One must have a mastery of the subject material to condense a problem definition into a short 4 minute video. I have found this level of performance consistent across multiple classes.

For now, I have finished the machine learning part, which is the first part of the course. First of all, the language of expression was very explanatory, simple and well designed for teaching. Secondly, I will talk about the narrative structure of the subjects again, because explaining the subject and then asking questions or exercises about it and sharing different resources provide better learning. Third, the feedback given in the project evaluation was helpful.

The course itself is very good, and I liked very much the logical and mathematical explanations of the various algorithms, but the (first) project asked to me to know or search on the web different things, not seen in the previous lessons, and I didn't like it at all, considering I'm paying to be teached what I'm supposed to know, and considering that a knowledge of the most popular machine learning models, their pros and cons and how to approach a model comparison and evaluation are very important concepts than cannot be delagated to web search, which is free and I could do on my own also without paying a course.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning with TensorFlow
description: The Introduction to Machine Learning with TensorFlow program covers supervised and unsupervised learning methods for machine learning. Course 1 introduces regression, perceptron algorithms, decision trees, naive Bayes, support vector machines, and evaluation metrics. Course 2 focuses on neural networks and creating an image classifier. Course 3 covers unsupervised learning methods, including clustering and dimensionality reduction for customer segmentation. Key skills include data preprocessing, model selection, and evaluation using TensorFlow and Python.
skills_learnt: Naive bayes classifiers , Gaussian mixture models , Model evaluation , Support vector machines
prerequisites: Basic descriptive statistics , Python for data science , Basic probability

Excellent Nanodegree program! Principles and practices of machine learning are covered with very well-structured content, video lessons and amazing real-world projects. Mentors and reviewers are very helpful with guidance, feedback and recommended references. It is worth doing this program if you not only want to learn the fundamentals but also get hands-on practice with machine learning (Supervised Learning, Deep Learning and Unsupervised Learning).

pros: 1. the first project covers the primary steps in supervised learning I've learned to resolve a real world problem which is helpful to practice and review the machine learning knowledge. 2. each lesson is broken into small sections and each section takes several minutes to cover a small topic. This design is good. I can stop learning anywhere in a lesson and easy to continue to learning in the lesson when i'm back.  cons: 1. my feeling is the course doesn't cover much details about several supervised learning topics. It can be used as a guideline and i need to learn from other sources (from internet or machine learning books) to have a better understanding about the topics. Or probably the course encourages student to learn from external sources. That's a good practice for senior learners in ML, but it really takes much time and sometimes costs confusion about the concepts for a beginner to learn from external sources. Overall, I think this course still helps me to learn machine learning on entry level and the mentors helps a lot.

title: AWS Cloud Architect
description: The AWS Cloud Architect program focuses on designing highly available, reliable, and resilient systems and networks using AWS infrastructure. It covers availability zones, regions, building for resiliency, business objectives, security, monitoring, reacting, and recovering. Learners will also understand the differences between traditional data centers and cloud infrastructure and how to design, provision, and monitor infrastructure using open-source tools. Additionally, the program covers cost and monitoring, high performance, servers and security groups, storage and databases, and securing access to cloud services and infrastructure. Throughout the program, learners will practice designing for performance and scalability, recovering from failure, and securing cloud infrastructure.
skills_learnt: AWS availability zones , Cloud security in AWS , Terraform , Cloud performance management
prerequisites: Application architecture , Basic web development , Object-oriented programming basics

title: Sensor Fusion
description: The Sensor Fusion Engineer Nanodegree program consists of four courses that teach the fundamentals of sensor fusion and perception for self-driving cars. The program covers lidar, radar, camera, and Kalman filters, and includes lessons on working with real-world data, filtering, segmentation, clustering, and object tracking. In addition, students will work on a capstone project that involves building a complete sensor fusion pipeline for autonomous vehicles. Upon completing the program, graduates will have the skills and knowledge necessary to design and implement sensor fusion systems for self-driving cars.
skills_learnt: Radar , Sensor fusion , Digital cameras , Kalman filters
prerequisites: Basic calculus , Basic probability , Intermediate C++

My rating is just based on the first course and project. On the plus side, I have found it very helpful and adding to my skills I have already gained through my job experiences with Power BI desktop. An enhancement I would suggest is to demo the handling of uploading the individual dimension tables for the star schema versus a single table upload from a custom view (such as from a SQL server environment). I've run into this latter situation in a recent work contract. The single view gave me some interesting challenges on the DAX side for formulas. On the negative side, I have none really. The program develops your confidence in using the application and building small star schema/ data mart/data models in PBI. I will say that if you have used Power Pivot when they were simple add-ins to Excel and modeled in Excel, you will find the beginning a bit of a refresher. And the only real critique I have is that I would have liked to have more practice (or at least demoed!) loading data into power bi desktop not just from individual files but from other sources - simulating a corporate environment if that was possible.
I am learning quite a bit.  If I hadn't already had some experience in using Power BI, I would have found this pretty difficult.  With that said, I do like how it is structured.
The reviewers like java or javascript syntax check errors. There is no bargain or pity like wrongly typing uppercase or lowercase.....  Awesome

The quizzes and exercises really cement the concepts and the first project was challenging but structured in such a way that was helpful when I needed to go back and clarify.

title: Intermediate Python
description: Python is a general-purpose coding language with applications in web development, data science, machine learning, fintech, and more. The Intermediate Python Nanodegree program equips you to leverage the capabilities of Python and streamline the functionality of applications that perform complex tasks, such as classifying files, data mining a webpage, etc. By the end of the program, you’ll have a portfolio that demonstrates your ability to apply practitioner-level Python skills on the job.
skills_learnt: File i/o , Functional programming concepts , Python data structures , Python library fluency

reviews.content: It was perfect and i understand everything and i have make it more strength in applied projects
Amazing course!
It has improved my python skills and paved a way for further learning.
Excellent Instructor
I wish that there was more examples to work with just for practice
Super practical and useful.

A lot of the important concepts where brought together in one nice big package and the concepts taught were implemented in a project to be able to really understand the Hows and the Whys of using them.

This is a very challenging Nanodegree. I enrolled after finishing the Intro to Programming, and I can say that Intermediate Python is much more advanced. The lessons are very valuable and the instructors are great. When I first started to work on the projects I thought I wasn't going to be able to finish them but the Knowledge platform is definitely very valuable.  You will struggle with this Nanodegree, but you will learn a lot.

You learn so much being a more professional Python Software Engineer. The first NEO project is like 'real world' projects, having bugs, need to debug, thinking about better architecture and algorithms and nothing for beginners. I am curious working on the second project. So, the course fits to my expectations :-)
I really learnt o lot, especially abaout OOP

Lectures are short and quite condensed. One needs to really concentrate, however if you do you learn very efficiently.  It seems that the content of the advanced python technices lectures was really all used in the project.  Overall i am in particular impressed by the didactical strength of the course so far.
It's great. It gives me basic but important knowledge which definitely changes the whole way I work with Python and makes my code look professional.

The program was good. Projects are difficult. Project 2 was easier than project 1. Overall, I had a nice experience with the course. Mentor replied quickly. However, I would like to see more content that is required for the projects.
It is a great learning experience for me. I need some advices about the next step. in my python learning.  Thanks.
more challenging that what i excepted that's good
The course is really good, informative. I dislike the workspace as it is glitchy. I even made a report about the issues, along with  bringing it up to the project reviewer.

Solid course overall. Both instructors are very knowledgable and explain topics in an understandable way. The projects are fun and great ways to cement learning. My one critique:  I wish the second module had more depth & detail compared to the first module. It seems to zip through a lot of topics.
Demanding, but very good and enjoyable!
This is a very comprehensive program. The content is good.

I like that the videos are short and concise. It helps a lot in keeping you engaged. The Near-Earth-Project is a nice exercise that shows how to handle data and how can that be done.
I have learned a lot in the first part, so I am enjoying the program very much.

great!

a lot of things:  write clean code by rules,  work with big data in csv, json formats,  make searching by name and other filters and make it faster,  i deeply learned about python foundamentals like functions, data types/structures, OOP. there's a lot of things to count. THANK YOU!
I thought this first project was great; just enough hand-holding to get me on my way, but challenged me to implement some new concepts as well.
Yes I enjoyed the project and learnt a lot. My only critique is that I found the web based code editor did not make the code linting easy.
This first half was perfect! challenging, and the project really felt like you were the one doing most of the work
The project did not cover all the things I learned such as decorators

The first project was very strict on PEP8 and PEP257 so much so that my project was asked to be resubmitted multiple times however, the last resubmissions, I in fact, had adjusted the code as the mentors had asked but, what I learned was that the project workspace was not saving my code or it wasn't being cached, some timing issue was occurring. When I would log off, after submitting, the mentor posted pictures of my code in a previous state, without adjustments made but, in fact, I had made those corrections in the project workspace. I recall running pycodestyle on the files and remembering it didn't pick up on immediate changes (within 1-2 minutes), I would have to wait about 2 minutes to run pycodestyle again. I reported a ticket with support however, they could not assist.   I found the NEO project to be fascinating and would have very much preferred to have learned or gone more in depth to the structure of main.py and overall how the project was setup. Most of it was setup by Udacity but, in fact, as a student I would have benefited from learning that aspect as well.
Very interesting and valuable knowledge!
Love the program, very informative and pretty well self-contained. Y'all should make an advanced python nanodegree - I would take it.

Loved the assignment. Thanks for setting it up so well.  The pycodestyle and pydocstyle linters were a little too noisy and I was wondering if there were ways to make them less aggressive. It took a couple of hours for me to fix all the lint errors.
You learn a lot about Python. The most I like is the practical focus, which makes one employable and ready for projects.
It was awesome!!!

I would say that the support was very good. Indeed many people are complaining it is difficult, but this is an intermediate python course. I would agree it was difficult for me, probably because I had only studied python for 2 weeks (quite intensively) prior to starting it.

Even though initially I found this project bit challenging, while doing I was able to able to understand the project requirements exactly .The knowledge platform was really helpful. Also , the elaborate review from the reviewers really helped me in completing the project.

This is an interesting project. I submitted twice, each time it kept me focused for hours on end. While working on the project, I encountered some quite difficult things like starting to define the database component format and linking the two classes together, handling the filter and query part. With the first data binding it was quite confusing for me so I failed a lot of tests on the first submit, but actually the second time doing it actually looking back it was really simple. The filter creation did not follow the instructions, I needed to add a variable to make it easier to determine the value to compare from the database. With testing the program, I often fail and error because defining the wrong input variable data format makes the output different than expected. Those are some of my experiences when working on this project, after working with the mentor's project helped me better understand some knowledge and some experience when programming a project in python.
The program meets all my expectations. It is a very challenging program so I used a lot the responses of the mentors given to others who were stuck in the same topics as me.
Excellent!! I'm expecting you guys to release advanced python class, already.
yes definitely! Fun experience & learning!

title: Data Streaming
description: Learn the latest skills to process data in real-time by building fluency in modern data engineering tools, such as Apache Spark, Kafka, Spark Streaming, and Kafka Streaming.
skills_learnt: Faust , Confluent Kafka Python client , Kafka rest proxy , KSQL
prerequisites: Intermediate Python , ETL , Basic descriptive statistics

reviews.content: Program is tough but at the same time very exciting. Yes, it has definitely matched my needs and expectations.

Great Project!  all aspects of kafka topics,  producer/consumer/ksql and schema registry very well covered to give a feel of how it can utilized. The project was very carefully crafted to provide the experience of utilizing the APIs and the interaction

Lots of great materials, and instructor videos are an effective way to learn.  Doing the exercises helps solidify the concepts while still having clear guidance as to not be lost. The projects were a good way to link several concepts together to produce a working data stream.  Project reviews were timely, useful, and accurate, and linked to useful materials for areas I got wrong.
Yes the program has been successful in imparting the practical knowledge
The kafka project really push student to understand all essential concepts, and the project structure is a good reference for knowing how kafka componets work with each other.
Great Learning!!
There is a steep learning curve, but also a lot of topics outside this course that were not addressed in the course specification. That got me into a lot of unexpected additional work.
Hoping to learn how to implement the kafka cluster from the ground up in the next program
The Project was amazing and will definitely help to gain industry knowledge.

The good: I got through the first part of the Udacity Data Analysis course.  Then I started working, and I did not see the value added of doing the second part of the course.  I felt that I was competent for Data Analysis Python.  I first learned programming in 1991 with Pascal and Ingres.  At that time, you had to build your own modules and functions. These days open source offers many possibilities to use already built functions and classes.  But open source documentation is a challenge.  At work, I am a SQL Data Engineering System Analyst.  My team has great best practices using Kimball in Sybase.   I feel like I am an SQL native and I translate into Python, but frequently I use Udacity Python less to translate into Sybase SQL. SQL is not what it was in 1991 - there are more possibilities.   I had an understanding of object oriented programming, but did not have even academic experience.  At work, we have built using Sybase Data Service what I think of as object oriented SQL - I think the project will help be better understand development as needed - I am so busy that I cannot get down to programming details - and I have great colleagues.  We will also be changing technical platforms so the Object oriented experience will help.  Learning Kafka basics, of course is great. An added bonus was learning basic JSON. It took extra effort, but it was good to challenge learning new things.  The framework is a great example of decoupled architecture.  I had never programmed  in a Linux/Unix so the Udacity workspace is a great.   I think Udacity has always been good with project reviews, but I think the Data Streaming is even better. They hold Udacity standards, but also teach.   To improve:  At work we have a framework that we work with.  The general rule is the developer needs to add his SQL to the framework.   The developer cannot change the framework without the express consent of the Lead Developer - if a developer does this he/she will not be in the team for long.  In the Project directions, we had incomplete instructions.  We had to change the framework for the project to work.  For me it was challenging, but it is not good practice to change frameworks (e.g. server.py, producer.line.py)   I have noted that in the internet documentation and also in the Udacity course, the examples are not end to end - or  very rarely.  If I would want to be a python/kafka  professional programmer, I would add end to end examples to the documentation - but work comes first. In the Data Analysis course, I had a bigger challenge with renewing or fully understanding statistics - Udacity also taught this very well.  But I thought the Data Analysis  lectures were more end to end then  Data Streaming lectures in the first part of the course.   On the whole the Udacity workspace is great.  But there are sometimes infrastructure problems - there were 2 days of macro problems.  But 1-2 times a week there would be micro problems.  In the start, I thought my software was the problem, but I got to now that there were infrastructure problems.   In the Data Analysis course, Udacity tried to organize meeting with mentors.  This did not work.  It would be nice if you could request a meeting - e.g. x minutes of requested meeting in a project.   Sometimes going through mentor responses is like stackoverflow, sometimes the response are quite helpful - I am really thankful for the help I got for producer.weather.py - turns out with a typing error in topic name you will not get a python or kafka error.   Conclusion:  My goal is to be a well rounded Data professional.   At work, our business want to use more data streaming.  I have noticed that there are not many who understand SQL Data Engineering and Data Streaming.  The course is taking more effort then expected, but I feel that I am reaching that goal.

title: Data Visualization
description: This Data Visualization Nanodegree program covers four courses on data visualization and storytelling. Students will learn to select appropriate visualizations, design effective dashboards, and tell data stories that uncover insights and make recommendations. They will use Tableau to build interactive dashboards and create polished presentations with data visualizations. Through a series of projects, students will learn to discover user needs, identify key metrics, prototype, and design dashboards, analyze data to find insights and communicate recommendations effectively.
skills_learnt: Animated data visualizations , Flourish , Data storytelling , Data limitations and biases
prerequisites: Explanatory data analysis , Basic computer literacy , Basic descriptive statistics

title: AI for Healthcare
description: The AI for Healthcare program offers two courses that apply AI to 2D and 3D medical imaging data. The first course covers fundamental skills needed to work with 2D imaging data, such as extracting images from DICOM files, building AI models, and obtaining regulatory approval. The course project involves training a CNN to classify chest X-rays for the presence of pneumonia and writing an FDA validation plan. The second course covers 3D imaging data, including clinical fundamentals, imaging modalities, and common analysis tasks. It also explores how AI can be integrated into the clinical workflow. Both courses are designed to teach students how to derive clinically relevant insights from medical imaging data using AI.
skills_learnt: Feature engineering , Medical and healthcare regulations and standards , Medical imaging basics , Fda medical device framework
prerequisites: Data cleaning , Machine learning frameworks in Python , Basic supervised machine learning

This is my second class with Udacity and while I have enjoyed both classes and learned a great deal, I seem to have run into the same problems over and over. I don't like the general fraternity hazing attitude of many of the mentors/participants. I think it is a reflection of the general stereotype of the tech industry -- an insider's only club. I think the coaching could be a bit less adversarial. I am taking these classes for personal interest and am not competing for anyone's job; so I don't see the need for the 'prove you're good enough' attitude to join the club!

title: AI For Business Leaders
description: Formulate and evaluate proposals grounded in first principles when assessing opportunities to embed machine learning and artificial intelligence into a corporate strategy.
skills_learnt: Machine learning fluency , Beta testing , Machine learning dataset fundamentals , Machine learning system architectures

reviews.content: An excellent framework and a detailed methodology to filter use cases in data-driven projects.

I was aware that a Udacity Nanodegree was among the most challenging courses one could take. Indeed it was! I was looking for a programme to teach me how framing AI/ML projects, by following a scientific method and isolating the individual elements that need to be addressed to solve it. Definitely exceeded my expectations!
How's the program going?  --> Great! How has it matched your needs and expectations?  --> Great!

very good mixture of theory, its repetition (quizzes, assignments), and a practical part required for submission. You will learn to work out such a project, from investigating for information, structuring information you have, draft presentation concluding into  final one.

Definitely exceeded my expectations! Very comprehensive coverage of the topic and well organized. From an executive point of view, it was a terrific start into the world of AI and ML! For some of the topics it¬¥s clear that I¬¥ll need to put additional effort in order to have more confidence when applying this knowledge in an actual project, but the overall perspective and learning process was amazing. Thank you all!
This program has certainly met my expectations and leaves me wanting to learn much more about how to apply AIML to practical and business use cases.
Amazing support and review process.  Thanks Udemy!
The program was challenging but that is good. I only go for watch challenges me.
Perfect match! Provided use cases are very representative to my professional challenges.
I love it!
Good high level overview of the fundamentals of AI/ML and its implementation

The whole program was pretty interesting and i definitely love these learning videos as i can learn it when its needed, or go back to them anytime.  What i didnt like was the blog post, i could read (studies etc) I felt like there was just randomly chosen to 'just' read them and from my side, it was not that effective.  I just skipped them and googled stuff around and found articles that are shorter and more stright forward or much clearer for me.  Overal, everything else was great !

So grateful for all the learnings. As a Data Scientist it sometimes is not easy for me too understand the business side as I am lacking methods. This was a great start for me in this area. Thanks for all the links provided for improving myself in this area :)
Great course to get started in AI for business.
Very thorough and a great challenge. Definitely had to work hard and spend some well thought out time to get through all of the projects.
It was fantastic
The beginning was stronger than the end. Project work should be reduced, instead increase in content on AI techniques.

I have to say that I absolutely loved this course and this project. It allowed for a very subjective approach of very real problems facing the business world. Love that the project review was so detailed and very good to understand. Wonderful that the reviewer tried to see everything from my perspective and graded on the basis of that. Thank you so much.
Amazing for no technical professionals
I had high expectations for this program. I learned a few interesting things about delivering an AI strategy, but I was expecting more depth on technical aspects.

The course is very well structured and gives a logical approach/framework to analyze Use Cases to find out their suitability for a Machine Learning based solution.  I must specifically mention the kind of help I received from the mentors  in the forums. Every question or doubt that I had, was responded within an hour. The answers and explanations were very clear and always accompanied with examples.  All in all very good Program with good support from mentors, met all my expectations
Concepts and their connection to the real world problems are very well done.
Great
good!
The program covered all I wanted to know about and more.

It was great.

It was a great course! Content, exercises, extra learning materials and of course, the final project! This course really makes your think strategically and you start feeling the world of AI in some sense
It gave me good understanding of AI and the project had practical impact where I had to do a research and build architecture. Love Udacity!
great program!

It was a great learning experience and provided a good breadth of topics at reasonable detail to help get started with the AI journey in my organization.  The project was challenging, although I feel the documentation needed for it can be simplified.

The program is great! For that price I would like to add one more suggestion: Have based on how many users at any given time a couple of live discussions (like a panel) with industry CDOs CTOs telling their stories and experiences and allow students to ask questions at the end.
Yes. Although, for an 8-week program, I would have wanted more technical material. Else, I recommend reducing the soft side length to make a 4-week program.

One of the most challenging programs that I've ever taken. This is a paradigm shift if you have a mid or low knowledge level.  Thanks to Udacity and BMW Group for this terrific program. Thanks to William Ross Luis Serrano and Joshua Bernhard; you guys were great support during this executive program.  Looking forward for more!  ‚ÄúThose who can imagine anything, can create the impossible.‚Äù ‚Äï Alan Turing
The program was interesting and met my expectations. I intend to continue the studies in this area. Congratulations on the program and all the support offered to students.

Looking back after being done, I see a lot of value and I am glad that I did it.  I would have like more flexibility in the pricing. I ended up paying a lot of money for it. I know it is my fault but given pandemic and work/family pressure, I wish Udacity would have been more flexible with my request on this regards. If you can still do something about it, I would appreciate a credit towards another nano-degree or a refund but just the credit will be great.
The AI for Business Leaders Executive Program gave me a good understanding of structuring decision processes for future AI applications.
was fun, thanks!
A great way to start your journey in ML/AI
Great primer, excellent project journey!
Great! It was a fantastic learning experience.

The program's structure was well designed and thorough. I wish the explanations for how to estimate time/cost for each architecture were more detailed since I'm still struggling with that. Overall a good start for anyone looking to introduce AI into a corporate setting and wants to be able to understand the plethora of technical jargon around it.
Meet expectatons!
I really enjoyed it. It was a good mix of theory and practical business applications. I also liked that you could choose your own business to work on.

The program is insghtful, but, after having completed multiple of them, I would say that it is a bit too expensive, or it should be bundled with another course such as AI product development for example.
Very well, I can work with that framework with customers to evaluate, which AI projects are more or less valuable for them. Thank you very much. :-)
I really enjoyed this program, nevertheless I would have expected to have more feedback on the final project....

At times there were topics or steps in the reasoning process of the presenter that I felt lacked better explanation of how it got there. Overall it fully matched my expectations and I'll be delving further into Udacity's offering for more of these executive decision-making oriented programs.

It was really nice. Help me understand the implications of AI technologies not jut from a technical perspective but also from a business perspective. The material was pretty clear to understand, and I liked the links for additional optional information. Btw, I loved the explanatory videos with diagrams and graphs, it made it a lot easier to understand and remember. Great programme!
Great experience going through this program!

It was a good program to introduce how ML/AI strategies are built. But the program is not enough for someone to transition into a new role. Some hands-on practice with AutoML tools like H2O's Driverless AI or/and other similar tools will be helpful.

Great experience!

very strong introduction this new Technology

Udacity is a great option to choose to learn applicable cutting-edge skills such as Machine Learning, Data Science, Cloud Computing, the list goes on!!!

I did a lot of courses and nanodegree that were mostly technical. This one was really interesting because it makes you think about how to evaluate AI in your company but also in general.   However, some parts were confusing on the final project where it was difficult to understand what it was asked to do. For example, it was asked to select 2 use cases and on the following survey form, 3 use cases are present which in my opinion doesn't make sense. The survey should help us to decide which of the 3 use cases we want to select to go further.  I like the framework proposal and all given keys to help you decided if your project is feasible focusing on data-driven business.
I really loved it. It's a nice feeling when you get to the end after all these weeks. It makes you want to start another one immediately! :)

The content of this entire program is well organized which made me learn what I was exactly looking for ML/AI strategy  . Thanks to Udacity of this great course !
great stuff
The executive program matched my expectations well. I particularly liked the project with relevance to my own work experience.
Really good, thanks!
It was a great learning journey.

When this new nano degree (AI for Business Leaders) was announced by Udacity earlier this year, I was curious and eventually decided to enroll, and I am so glad I did; it was a well-rounded program with a challenging capstone project.  I am looking forward to exploring and learning more about this subject and applying these valuable skills to solve some interesting problems.

This project nailed it for me!   I had been chasing down the technical side of AI/ML by reading many books and hundreds of articles, auditing AI & ML courses including Udacity, Stanford CS229, doing the python exercises and even wrote the handwriting neural network from scratch in C# and a NN demo with equations in an Excel spreadsheet. Its like living on the edge of fractal, its beautiful, its fun, but you never get to the bottom.   I felt a little lost, even dismayed. I wanted to apply AI/ML to real work and I didn't want to be playing at it.  Amazingly,  some of the customers I'm working with right now are asking us to help them implement Industry 4.0, become Digitally Mature and create Smart Factories for the future, and now, I see a path forward thanks to this course!  I believe I have successfully navigated through the Dunning-Kruger valley of despair and am well up along the slope to enlightenment!  Thanks Udacity

title: Introduction to Cybersecurity
description: In this program, you will learn how to evaluate, maintain, and monitor the security of computer systems. You’ll also learn how to assess threats, respond to incidents, and implement security controls to reduce risk and meet security compliance goals.
skills_learnt: Threat intelligence , Cryptography , Cybersecurity fluency , Security auditing
prerequisites: Operating system fundamentals , Command line interface basics

reviews.content: everything is great!
So far, the program is going as planned. I am doing my part to make sure I graduate and finish within the required time.
wI am learning a lot. but I wish the videos were a little longer
The program is going great, I am learning a lot. It has matched my needs and expectations well. My professors are great at what they do and the courses are very detail.
So far the program is very informative!

The program has been good so far! I am a little behind coming from no background in networking and IT, but the pace has been manageable for me. I've also appreciated all of the extra readings to help fill in my knowledge gap. The 1st project helped tremendously get me hands on experience digging through security preferences to understand the fundamentals of securing a PC. Would recommend!
The programe is very exciting  and I see it matched my needs and expectations.
Its going very well, so far I'm learning exciting material.  Very good course

The course content is quite comprehensive and so far well meeting my expectations. Looking forward for the rest!  The project was not so difficult and not so easy, it was on a well-planned balance. It covered all aspects we went through.  Thanks for all.
I'm very much enjoying the program and what I have learned so far. This program was everything I was looking for. My needs and expectations are fully met.
great
Yes, it's been very exciting. I am learning a lot and I can get hands-on which is very great
let's see :) ...not ready to review, yet. so far so good. it's fun up to now. looking forward to continue

Overall, the program is going very well. It is slightly uneven in difficulty at times - detailed discussions of policy and standards at some point, elementary Windows configuration at other - but I didn't mind this too much. This sense may stem, in part, from the fact that I was previously in the industry and am using this to get back in practice as well as earn further credentials at my current job. And for that, the hands-on aspects are great!   Despite some minor quibbles with the details of Project 1, it was a lot of fun, and was a good excuse to dive back into the details of Windows policy, even beyond what the project required. My only real complaint here is that the document itself could use some polish and more consistent, precise language.

The program has taught me some valuable information so far on how to secure a windows 10 desktop pc. It is a good starting point for more advanced concepts in the future that I plan to pursue.  I am completely satisfied with the course and I would recommend to anyone starting in cybersecurity to take it.

The program is going very well. Learning the fundamentals first and having projects to apply them to is a great way to learn. Also the reviews are great and help out with fixing your own mistakes. The Knowledge center is great as well if you have any questions.
Program is pretty good.

The program is fine. I was surprised by the focus on Windows PCs, since I'm dealing with larger business application management which usually involves lot of linux servers, apache, databases and so on... Still, the program has provided me with very useful insights and tools and I'm looking forward to the next lessons.
Great!
yet, not as i expected but, the future content are actually exciting which im looking forwards to learn!!

Simple and easy to understand

The program is going really awesome, the concepts are clearly explained and had been a lot of reading shared so it complement really well all the things learned.  It is matching perfectly my expectations so far, and the best thing is the way to learn, that I can join after work any time I want.
I like having more practical content, theory is boring.

As an IS professional for more than 15 years I enjoyed digging into the Windows OS and learned a few things I didn't know but also learned a bit more about the how's and why's certain actions help to secure a workstation.
Yes it's going well - I'm really enjoying it - getting the first project out of the way successfully was a big bonus.
Its nice but it feels outdated

Also a few of the links were out of date so I would recommend updating those. But besides that the course is very good, a lot of grest information and I really liked the ability to use what I am learning. What I also thought was really awesome is that at the beginning of this week I started an IT job where I am a support specialist and the things that I learned in this program I was able to directly apply at my job. My familiarity with windows and th principles of securing a PC and understanding the professional way to do it has increased tremendously. For that I say thank you.

It is great and it is well worth the money that it costs.

IT has been a huge learning curve and the reviewer has been very very helpful as well as the mentor who has been there guiding me through. In-fact i have gained much insight through this as opposed to, if i had submitted the project and there was no problem whatsoever. i believe i have learnt more through the repeated efforts as opposed to getting it right the first time.
Love it! I am an IT professional of 15 years and I love that this program is teaching me things i never knew.
The program is very good! I'm very excited to dive in next classes!
I had great experience and I want to learn more . after I finish my course I will be ready to work I‚Äôm so happy to learn more thank you so much Udacity
Excellent

As a student who is new to both IT and Cybersecurity, the content thus far has been far more challenging than I had thought.  However, the teaching style and projects provide a great platform for learning and this has benefitted me greatly.  I am learning so much and am thankful I have the time to dedicate to my studies.    If I had to provide some advice to students considering the Nanodegree program in Cybersecurity, it would be this:  If you are brand new to both IT and Cybersecurity, and you have a full time job, it may be best to start with some of Udacity‚Äôs individual courses to familiarize yourself with the fundamentals prior to beginning the Nanodegree program.  If you have the time to devote to the program and you enjoy a challenge, you won‚Äôt be disappointed with this program.  I‚Äôve absorbed an incredible amount of knowledge so far!
Excellent.  It s different from what i am used to ( in a good way). The learning process is efficient.

I have only completed a small portion of the ND so far but it seems good. Apart from a few instructions being a bit unclear(installing the VM, a couple of questions in the first project), the program seems good so far.

I really like it.  It's a pretty good mix of hands on and tutorial videos.  There were some questions that were a little vague and therefore confusing.  And there were a couple of things in the project that weren't covered in the material.  Some of the material is a little outdated (e.g. CIS now only has 18 controls vs 20).  But overall, I like it.  When first signing up, I didn't not know we would need to set up an account with Azure, nor did I know what to expect with the projects.  So maybe a little more transparency about what you are getting into when you sign up would be good.
The program is going great! Material is good and it helps you learn what needs to be done at a practical level.
The experience is great. The course is all what I expected for a beginner class. I am looking forward to learning new technology.

The program is going well. Udacity has matched my needs and expectations. The course content clear and the mentors/reviewers are really good in answering questions and providing great feedback for the project.
This is the first program I took from curiosity. I think the teaching is good but the  project makes it great.
Perfectly, thank you
Every thing is going on the right way. But it needs more time to acquire all the concepts.

Thank you in advance for all your efforts. until now the program extended my knowledge about the basic things in cybersecurity, also increased the awareness about how can I protect myself and my community from any harmful things that may happen online.
Enjoyed and excited to learn more
It's good, honestly above my expectations with learning material, hands on projects and project review feedbacks. Thank you so much!
It's good I have to arrange and manage my time but other than that it's good
its been really good. i learned a lot  I like the program so far
I enjoyed the project. It was fun!
This program has matched my needs and exceeded my expectations. Very practical and hands-on. The first project has been a confidence booster on my part. Keep up the good work.
Submission requirements could be more clear but having a good time learning
So far so good!

I am very much happy with this program as I am doing this course with aim of understanding more about the space and training security-aware mindset. However I think if I were considering to become cyber security specialist,  I'd be concerned about the depth of the knowledge I am gaining here. I'd certainly add more readings and some tests, at least as optional
it's perfect until now.
Everything has felt very real world, I like it!
I really learned alot!
I think it is too early to give a proper review of the nanodegree, because I am only one quarter through it. So far, it has been challenging and intriguing, so I hope those qualities continue.
So far So good it would be best if there is some sort of a checklist for the concepts that need to be memorized by heart

I have 2 years of work experience already. A good bit of that having to do much of what was covered in this section.  However, I still learned quite a bit.  In particular, more efficient ways to do things, CIS and NIST, etc.  I feel like you guys filled in the gaps to my self-learning.  Looking forward to more advanced topics to come.
So far so good. It is great and looking forward for continuing the path!

Great, but the management of the Azure account has given me some problems.  It should be stated that an Azure account should be needed, and that it is almost certain that a payment has to be done (unless you create 3 free paid accounts).

Good info ‚Äî¬†maybe make it clearer that this is truly aimed at beginners (I do realize it says 'Intro...').  VERY PAINFUL: The Joe's Garage VM setup on Azure was _awful_. The size of the VM provisioned cannot reasonably support the image. The forums are bursting at the seams with people saying the same, so I imagine you all are aware.
A good introduction and usage of Windows services to secure a Windows PC
The program has been going fairly smooth so far. I think videos setting up the VMs may be a little helpful. However, that would be my only note.
Yes it has. The program is very interactive and I am liking the exercises that lead up to the project

The knowledge curse give is super useful and professional on one hand. On other, I had many problems with set up virtual machines, and my not best English also slows down my studies. But I like and recommend it for everybody at all, it's very exciting.
Yes, it's been great!
Everything is great. I‚Äôm learning so much with a lot of fun.
So far things are going well. The Curriculum is well structured in a way that it makes us to really engaged in our studies and encourage us to move on through lessons on after another.

Its going good. I find CyberSecurity to be a fun topic to learn about. Yes, it has matched my needs and expectations. I am trying to get my first nanodegree hopefully I can do it.  I am enjoying this class. Cybersecurity is an interesting topic.
It's a challenging but great experience, it feels that all my efforts in the project are paid off , feel motivated to continue the lesson and other challenging projects!
The program is great and let's move at my own pace
I am really enjoying learning with Udacity. I can't wait to get to my next project. You guys did an amaizing job with this cybersecurity course.
I learned many things from this project, and I`m so excited to learn more..
it was ok.
I am having a lot of fun and learning a lot!
Great.
Everything is great!
My first project was mostly fun to complete. I wish some of the questions on the project were a little more clear, but overall, I enjoyed it and can't wait to continue on.
Had good experience working on the project although had to face few challenges along the line. Support was great!

That VM is slow. I wonder if I'm burning through the minutes. The person who reviewed my project said I could add RAM to the VM, so I will try that to speed things up if I have more Windows projects. Otherwise, project seems fine. I think I'm making up for getting my education before Cybersecurity was a thing. It would probably be wise to have a 'securing a linux machine' project as well, but maybe something like that is coming up.
It is very good.  The projects and the video lessons are very helpful.

I think that the program has good content in it. However, the fact that the students aren't too active and forthcoming to help others can be frustrating at times. The instructions provided to us can also be very confusing at times leading us to be unsure of what is required to be completed in the tasks assigned.
Program has been really informative. The videos are short and have just enough info to arouse interest and motivate to dig deeper into related topics.
Trying to focus automotive side of cybersecurity. Eagerly waiting to extend or have some training added to this nanodegree as optional.

title: Java Programming
description: This Nanodegree program is intended to elevate your Java abilities and teach you the fundamental skills used by Java developers to design, code, test and deploy cutting-edge Java software.
skills_learnt: Java collections , Maven , Java data types , Java inheritance
prerequisites: Functional programming , Basic Java , Basic computer programming

reviews.content: Pretty good actually.
I really like it so far! There are some small issues, but advantages clearly overweight them. I've just done the first out of three projects in the program.

The project is perfect except for the mentors. They don't respond to your questions. Life has its own curves. We're busy with other stuff while struggling with finishing the projects. Luckily, it is a self paced program with a possibility of extending your course work. I like the course materials and project feedback.
It is really awesome. It is very engaging
I like how the program lead us to explore more java basis on our own. And the Q&A forum absolutely is one of the most helpful resources!
very good
It is going well, enjoying it so far :)
it helps a lot, since the concept flow into my brain naturaly by finsh the project. When I am confuse and finally get a result, it makes me focus more on the detail of it, I love this learning style
So good.
It's a little bit challenging but rewarding
This project was very interesting. This was my first time doing something like this. Creating this project was a challenge for me but I enjoyed the process and was satisfied with the result.

The java fundamental program is great. It helps me strengthen my knowledge about  java and gave me a chance to pick up the areas that I omit in my work as a programer. Thanks for providing this course.
I'm very satisfied with Nanodegree program, very useful, contents simply e very intuitive. I expect to continue growing up my knowledge of programming.
For now everything is ok
Improve my coding ability from  professional aspect
VERY GOOD

the content of the course is not rich, you had to look elsewhere.
So far so good

Very well.

good project

The instruction is excellent.  The exercises are very effective.  I would like to see a consolidated reading-list with, perhaps, some exercises relevant to some of the more abstract ideas like singularities and command-line error checking.
The program is going well! It is a right choice for any beginner with basic knowledge of logic and algorithms.  Mentors help fits your needs precisely

Thanks for mentors help. And thanks for their patient to help go through the first project. I want to give some suggestion. When I did project, some of requirement is not clarify such using one default, one public, one private. I could not find them in the list of requirement.

title: AWS Machine Learning Engineer Nanodegree
description: The goal of the AWS Machine Learning Engineer (MLE) Nanodegree program is to equip software developers/data scientists with the data science and machine learning skills required to build and deploy machine learning models in production using Amazon SageMaker. This program will focus on the latest best practices and capabilities that are enabled by Amazon SageMaker, including new model design/deployment features and case studies in which they can be applied to.
skills_learnt: Neural network basics , Deep learning fluency , Sagemaker jumpstart , Machine learning framework fundamentals
prerequisites: AWS familiarity , Intermediate Python , API proficiency

reviews.content: This is the best program to learn ML and AWS together
Everything is out of my expectation. The courses are well-designed and teach ML step by step which eliminate any possible confusion.

I'm loving it but it's very challenging to be honest. Hoping to make up for lost time this month. Also, I have anxiety from running out of AWS billing. I ran a little wild with trials on the first project. I think the 25$ should be a bit higher to allow students to experiment with their analysis. Other than that, so far so good
If possible, I recommend add as content of module, material that describes how to use hyperparameters with AutoGluon. It will increase our study time.
So far so good.
Excellent program and so much to learn about. Udacity should give a course for at least one year to have it in account. 5-Months is very less.

It is great so far, learned a few new things even though I am familiar with Machine learning!

title: Machine Learning DevOps Engineer
description: The Machine Learning DevOps Engineer Nanodegree program focuses on the software engineering fundamentals required to successfully streamline the deployment of data and machine-learning models in a production-level environment. Students will build the DevOps skills required to automate the various aspects and stages of machine learning model building and monitoring over time.
skills_learnt: Git , Machine learning ops troubleshooting , Dvc , Automated machine learning
prerequisites: Command line interface basics , Basic descriptive statistics , Jupyter notebooks

reviews.content: Awesome
Excellent course
nice project

I found the Machine Learning DevOps Engineer course really helpful. This course provided me with a lot of knowledge and increased my awareness related to building scalable systems, and monitoring and evaluating the performance of artificial intelligence applications in manufacturing. This is also a very good premise so that I can work more confidently and professionally in building good products in the future. I am really satisfied with the quality of the course.
I am liking its content.
Program is good and in details. It is just the start of bigger journey. Hoping for godo time with remaining course.
It's going great other than the fact that docker would have been much better than conda.
I think the project has given me a good idea on what i have learned

Very good. It was not easy, took me almost 8 of 10 weekends to write the code and cover all requirements. However, with this experience, I will be much faster in the future. Also learned a lot about unittest, logging, and had a practice in multiple aspects of python.

Everting fine ,contents are amazing mostly the 2nd and 4th Module are vert interesting and well explained. But the authors can have add more related documents and example. Though MLops is very vast , Please keep updating the nanodegree with recent best practices of MLops tools and tips. Adding example like streamlit ,azure cloud, docker intermediate level (must) and some robust Deep learning task make the nanodegree better. Add new contents with small video is also very good.

So far neutral

It's really a nice starting point  :)
It has exceeded my expectations. Very indepth knowledge on MLOps and lots of tools to learn. Directly applicabl knowledge to industry standard.

Pluses: I have been introduced to Weights and Biases, MLFlow, and hydra, which will come in handy in the tasks I perform on a daily basis.  The exercises so far have been pretty well defined and explained, and they are very well organized.   Minuses:   I think it would  be nice if the teachers and introducers aren't so obviously reading their dialogue from a screen.   I feel some concepts / topics are missing better explanation. For example, for Features that should be included in the inference pipeline and not in a Feature Store, there is no explanation on how to treat them during the training cycle.
Great

Project was reasonable, bit boring but necessary I suppose.
It is going perfect
The program is going well.  I think that the structure makes perfect since and I had fun building the first project.  Looking forward to keep up with the work

It's early to give a full grade full course. First part (clean code) was good, although creating tests for plots was a bit annoying as it's not clear what a test should be. I started with the second part and the lectures are informative and interesting. Looking forward to the project.  What I don't like about Udacity, in general, is that videos are too short. I'd prefer 10-15min videos with more concepts and more details.  Another thing I don't like is the web experience for programming, which was always a deal breaker for me, doing stuff in your browser interface. Fortunately, the first exercise was doable by providing a git account link. Hopefully, it will stay this way.
Still waiting for the next advanced modules
Just what I need.
I enjoy the lectures and I think the platform enables very interactive learning.
It has superseded my expectations as I am growing at a fast rate and well on course in being skilled enough to partake my dream job
really nice project!
very interesting and challenging
Clean code is a good way to start the ND
good so far
not bed

The course has been so far great. It starts with a brief motivation section in which the business case for MLOps is presented. The first module gives a Comprehensive introduction to clean coding practices, including logging and testing. The feedback I got after delivering my first project was specific and with the right level of detail. This feedback was also actionable and I believe it gave great guidance on how to improve.
It¬¥s really matching all my expectations, amazing until now
The program is going well, all material is great. As a suggestion, the auto-complete functionality is not enabled in the framework used for coding. It will help a lot.

The program is going well so far. I have learned about useful engineering and coding  best practices in the previous modules including - how to follow PEP8 coding practice, how to do testing and logging, how to write code that is modular, well documented and tested, and how to utilize GitHub for version control and project workflow.
First project has been really helpful explaining the principles of clean code. I can't believe how bad my code has been really until this point.
Great real world actual applicable lessons
It was good overall, but plotting graphs seem a little tedious work - like checking whether saved plots show labels correctly.

slightly underwhelming regarding the testing part. I was really looking forward to implementing a solid testing structure after watching some additional material on testing. Things that are important for testing is that they run independently and efficiently. A model can't be retrained for testing. But the starter script suggests you retrain the model. There is little guidance on good principles for writing tests.  I really like the clean code part though. It's something I can use now as well. Some more in depth knowledge wouldn't be too bad regarding pep8 standards though. It is a further reading, but it might be good if there were a general introduction. e.g. how should class names be written, how should method names be written, etc. Some good practices in code structure etc.
pretty good, I really like it!
The project workspace really sucks y'all, honestly super disappointed about it.
Nice, there is so much work but I really enjoy it.
The program is great!! I've learnt a lot of things already!
So far the program matches all my expectations.
Well constructed
Its explaining to detail
Everything is perfect at the moment
Very Nice! Mentors are so friendly and always ready to help! I like the learning process that is reinforced by real-world projects. This is what I was expecting from Udacity.  Cheers, Jelal
Got to learn many new things. The projects are worth it.
The program requires one to explore the field in order to complete the project which is a great way of learning!
The program is exciting. I like the concise videos and the challenging project so far.

All courses except the third are excellent.  The topic of the 3rd course is very interesting, but it is extremely poorly covered. The course is crude and unfinished, unlike the previous ones. I had to work a lot with documentation and the Internet, but then why take this course.
Great
